Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: "Green" Nanolithography Using Protein-based Photoresists

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is an urgent need to reduce the use of noxious chemicals as photoresists and developing solvents during lithographic processes in conventional nanofabrication. This collaborative research award addresses this fundamental issue in nano-manufacturing by using bio-compatible protein as the photoresist, eliminating the need of hazardous chemicals during micro/nano-lithography and reducing the associated safety costs. It will also facilitate the understanding of the fundamental mechanism of the interaction between biopolymer proteins and incident radiation, that is, changes in proteins upon exposure to light. The knowledge obtained of the physical and chemical properties of protein-based biopolymers is expected to be widely applicable to protein-photon, protein-electron and protein-ion lithography processes, paving the way for the next generation "green" nanomanufacturing. The collaboration between the two institutions combines their strengths in nano-fabrication and nano-characterization, respectively, and provides unique educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students. This includes educational activities comprising curriculum development, recruitment and retention of under-represented students, and outreach to schools. The collaborative research results will be broadly disseminated through technical publications, conferences and workshops, regular and short courses.

A set of protein-based biopolymers - including regenerated natural and recombinant proteins - will be analyzed in thin-film form to evaluate their suitability as the resist materials for nanolithography with only water as the developing solvent. Comprehensive studies of the physical and chemical properties of these biopolymers will be conducted at the nanoscale using scanning electron microscopy and scanning near-field optical microscopy to assess their resist performance under different lithographic conditions. The uses of protein-based biopolymers as resist and template materials for large-scale nanomanufacturing (e.g. roll-to-roll nanoimprinting) will be investigated as well. The research will also provide a new, cost-effective and eco-friendly methodology not only for pattern transferring but also for fabricating nanostructures that can serve as biointerfaces with the same or better resolution than conventional lithographic methods. This research, when implemented with high resolution characterization and lithography procedures, will find numerous applications including but not limited to biosensors, biophotonics, and biostructures for tissue engineering owing to the inherently superior biocompatibility compared to synthetic counterparts.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Naturally occurring materials provide a compelling template to reinterpret and, in some cases, simplify modern manufacturing while rendering it sustainable and green. In this work we used IR near-field microscopy and spectroscopy to study the functional bio-compatible polymers based on protein structures. The underlying mechanisms of the electron- or ion-induced nanoscale polymerization & depolymerization reaction in protein based biophotoresists are clearly identified with ~10 nm resolution using near-field nano-optics. A library of applicable biophotoresists developed from natural proteins and recombinant proteins that are compatible with major conventional nanolithography systems have been provided.

By Evaluating the theoretical and practical performance and limitations of those protein-based biophotoresists, it allows us to build new types of biopolymers: silk protein bricks, which can work as fundamental building blocks for functional nano-bio-engineering. We have a comprehensive evaluation of these "Protein Bricks" (e.g. strength, resolution, etching resistance, surface morphology, stiffness) and demonstrated that using conventional nanolithography techniques (e.g. electron beam lithography (EBL) and ion beam lithography (IBL)), we can pattern and immobilize functional molecules within nanoscopic, hierarchical protein structures. Manufacturing and assembly of 2D bio-nanopatterns and 3D bionanoarchitectures via protein bricks was systematically studied to yield bio-compatible heterostructures with shape and function on demand. Infrared near-field characterization of these protein bricks yields important nanoscale information including the spectroscopic features as well as the spatial resolution we can ultimately achieve (~13 nm). Furthermore, a precise protein photolithography for high-performance biopatterning using well-defined silk fibroin light chain (L-fibroin) as the basic resist material has been developed, which is compatible with conventional UV lithography.

Patterned Silk fibroin thin films using ion irradiation at various dosages have been fabricated and investigated under infrared scattering near-field optical microscope (s-SNOM) for the first time. The ion-regulated structural transitions of silk fibroin and its solubility in water has been deciphered. This progress provides important guidelines for utilizing silk fibroin as a dual-tone protein resist for all-water-based eco-friendly IBL, without the usage of toxic chemistry. Therefore, our work is a solid attempt to complement and potentially disrupt the current state of the art in synthetic photoresists dominated nanolithography techniques and to create an academic curriculum to introduce “green” nanomanufacturing to students and the wider public.

The PIs have broadly disseminated our work through journal publications and conference presentations. Short technical courses on protein-based “green” nanolithography techniques have be held regularly. More importantly, this collaborative research provided unique educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students with educational activities comprising curriculum development, recruitment and retention of under-represented students, and outreach to K-12. We have successfully broadcast to a wide group of students and community with the novel concept of “green reinterpretation” of biocompatible materials that can successfully interface with current technologies in strategically important areas such as advanced manufacturing, sustainable engineering, biomaterials, environmental science, and semiconductors.

 


Last Modified: 06/05/2019
Modified by: Mengkun Liu
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Naturally occurring materials provide a compelling template to reinterpret and, in some cases, simplify modern manufacturing while rendering it sustainable and green. In this work we used IR near-field microscopy and spectroscopy to study the functional bio-compatible polymers based on protein structures. The underlying mechanisms of the electron- or ion-induced nanoscale polymerization & depolymerization reaction in protein based biophotoresists are clearly identified with ~10 nm resolution using near-field nano-optics. A library of applicable biophotoresists developed from natural proteins and recombinant proteins that are compatible with major conventional nanolithography systems have been provided. By Evaluating the theoretical and practical performance and limitations of those protein-based biophotoresists, it allows us to build new types of biopolymers: silk protein bricks, which can work as fundamental building blocks for functional nano-bio-engineering. We have a comprehensive evaluation of these "Protein Bricks" (e.g. strength, resolution, etching resistance, surface morphology, stiffness) and demonstrated that using conventional nanolithography techniques (e.g. electron beam lithography (EBL) and ion beam lithography (IBL)), we can pattern and immobilize functional molecules within nanoscopic, hierarchical protein structures. Manufacturing and assembly of 2D bio-nanopatterns and 3D bionanoarchitectures via protein bricks was systematically studied to yield bio-compatible heterostructures with shape and function on demand. Infrared near-field characterization of these protein bricks yields important nanoscale information including the spectroscopic features as well as the spatial resolution we can ultimately achieve (~13 nm). Furthermore, a precise protein photolithography for high-performance biopatterning using well-defined silk fibroin light chain (L-fibroin) as the basic resist material has been developed, which is compatible with conventional UV lithography. Patterned Silk fibroin thin films using ion irradiation at various dosages have been fabricated and investigated under infrared scattering near-field optical microscope (s-SNOM) for the first time. The ion-regulated structural transitions of silk fibroin and its solubility in water has been deciphered. This progress provides important guidelines for utilizing silk fibroin as a dual-tone protein resist for all-water-based eco-friendly IBL, without the usage of toxic chemistry. Therefore, our work is a solid attempt to complement and potentially disrupt the current state of the art in synthetic photoresists dominated nanolithography techniques and to create an academic curriculum to introduce "green" nanomanufacturing to students and the wider public. The PIs have broadly disseminated our work through journal publications and conference presentations. Short technical courses on protein-based "green" nanolithography techniques have be held regularly. More importantly, this collaborative research provided unique educational opportunities to a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students with educational activities comprising curriculum development, recruitment and retention of under-represented students, and outreach to K-12. We have successfully broadcast to a wide group of students and community with the novel concept of "green reinterpretation" of biocompatible materials that can successfully interface with current technologies in strategically important areas such as advanced manufacturing, sustainable engineering, biomaterials, environmental science, and semiconductors.
